image_1.entity_name: Figure 1: An illustrative example of long-term and short-term interests in news reading
image_1.description: Neural News Recommendation with Long- and Short-term User Representations is the title of the paper discussing a new approach to personalized news recommendation.
image_1.reason: The image depicts a timeline illustrating the long-term and short-term interests in news reading, which aligns with the concept discussed in the paper 'Neural News Recommendation with Long- and Short-term User Representations'. The events on the timeline are examples of both long-term and short-term interests, as mentioned in the text.

image_2.entity_name: Figure 2: The framework of the news encoder
image_2.description: News Encoder is a component of the LSTUR approach, responsible for learning representations of news from titles, topics, and subtopics.
image_2.reason: The image clearly shows the framework of a news encoder, which processes news titles through word embeddings, CNN networks, and an attention network to generate a final representation. This aligns with the description of the NEWS ENCODER in the text.

image_3.entity_name: Figure 3: The two frameworks of our LSTUR approach
image_3.description: LSTUR is the neural news recommendation approach that includes both long- and short-term user representations.
image_3.reason: The image clearly illustrates the two frameworks of the LSTUR (Long-Short Term User Representation) approach for news recommendation systems. The diagrams depict the process of encoding user click history and candidate news to generate a score for news recommendation, which aligns with the description of the LSTUR approach in the text.

image_6.description: LSTUR refers to a news recommendation approach that outperforms baseline methods by capturing both long-term preferences and short-term interests of users.
image_6.reason: The image consists of two bar charts comparing the performance of different methods, including LSTUR-con and LSTUR-ini, in terms of AUC and nDCG@10. This aligns with the description of CNN+Att as a method that combines CNN and attention mechanisms to learn more informative news representations.
